abstract: Can the makers of generic drugs, like those of brand-name drugs, be sued for failing to warn users about the risks posed by their products?
snippet: Can the makers of generic drugs, like those of brand-name drugs, be sued for failing to warn users about the risks posed by their products?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that makers of brand-name drugs may be sued under state law for failing to warn consumers about the risks associated with their products. That decision, Wyeth v. Levine, was based in large part on the fact that such drug companies can sometimes change the labels on their products without permission from the Food and Drug Administration.

headline.main: Justices Hear Arguments in Generic-Drug Lawsuit
headline.print_headline: Justices Hear Arguments In Generic-Drug Lawsuit
